content.desc: The acceleration of technology has placed a growing importance on upskilling within the professional environment, creating a powerful long-term driver for the global education sector

data.data: Just decades ago, formal education stopped as soon as employment began, confining the sector’s potential market to the global population’s youngest cohorts. Now, as technology continues to shake up almost every industry and sector on the planet, workers embark on lifelong journeys of learning and upskilling as their roles – and the skills required to perform them – evolve rapidly and continuously.

Implications for the global education sector are huge. Companies and individuals of all ages increasingly perceive work as an ongoing quest to keep up-to-date with the latest technology and how it impacts working practices – creating a powerful long-term growth engine. “The march of technology now requires permanent upskilling in the workplace, and that makes education a lifelong pursuit,” says Phyllis Jordan, Associate Director of FutureEd, an independent think tank at Georgetown University’s McCourt School of Public Policy.

data.data: The digital revolution has already produced acute shortages in the skills that employers need to fill jobs. According to Manpower Group, the global recruitment firm, the global talent shortage reached a 16-year high last year, with three in four employers reporting difficulty in matching vacancies with people. “From manufacturing to marketing, transport to trade, employers cannot find the people they need with the right blend of technical skills and human strengths,” it concluded in its annual report of the talent-shortage landscape.

data.h3: The global talent shortage is intensifying
data.desc: Three in four employers struggle to find talent

data.data: At the same time, workers increasingly see upskilling as a highway to full-time employment. As McKinsey noted recently, “Employers in fields from healthcare to cyber security are struggling to find qualified workers, and online education can help adults of all ages quickly gain the skills needed to fill these positions.”

Offering the opportunity to upskill while on the job could be a powerful tool for companies seeking to attract and retain talent. According to a recent report by Microsoft, 76 per cent of employees said they would stay longer at a company if they could benefit from learning and development support.

data.desc: Three in four employers struggle to find talent

data.data: All this has coincided with at least three factors that are helping to fuel demand for education. First, the Covid-19 pandemic forced companies to invest heavily in digitisation, which has, in turn, created new requirements for workers to acquire the latest digital skills.

Second, the gender-equality movement is gaining ground, helping and encouraging millions of girls and women to access the education system, often for the first time. According to Unicef, only 49 per cent of countries have achieved gender parity in primary education; the story is similar or worse in the case of lower-secondary and secondary education.

Yet studies show that investing in girls’ education has a profound effect on national growth rates; ensuring that all girls complete secondary education by 2030 could boost developing countries’ gross domestic product by 10 per cent, on average, over the next decade.

data.h3: Potential contributions to NET GDP as a result of reaching 100% secondary completion rate for girls by 2030

data.data: Third, the technology boom within the education sector itself has opened the door to remote learning – a development that has the potential to eliminate traditional barriers such as limits to infrastructure or the distance students might have to travel. The e-learning market surpassed $315bn in 2021, and is projected to expand at a compound annual growth rate of 20 per cent between this year and 2028.

Despite education’s renewed potential, several challenges remain. Investment in new technology in the sector remains woefully low. According to Holon IQ, a research firm, less than 4 per cent of total sector spending is allocated to digital. “As a sector, education is a digital laggard” says the firm. “The knowledge economy and future skills require massive digital transformation, and, while accelerated through Covid-19, there is still far to go.”

data.data: Perhaps the biggest single challenge to the sector is governance and, in particular, regulation. Last year in China, ed-tech’s biggest market, the government’s sweeping changes to laws governing tutoring wiped billions of dollars off a swath of education start-ups – a stark reminder of the sector’s highly regulated nature. Holon IQ recently dropped 11 Chinese ed-tech start-ups from its list of the sector’s unicorns (start-ups valued at or above $1bn) citing “major changes in the Chinese education regulatory environment” as the cause.

Yet, as Jordan of FutureEd notes, the growing demand for learning and upskilling in the jobs market, the increasing demand for women’s education as a central pillar of the gender-equality movement, and the potential of technology and e-learning to deliver new learning and skills to a widening market, mark deep and long-term trends that are likely to play out over decades. “These trends are coming together, creating greater demand for education not only for young people but throughout people’s careers,” she says. “That is a terrific opportunity for the sector.”
